title: Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
added: === ''Bally v. Whitmer'' ===

On November 11, 2020, registered voters in Michigan filed suit against state officials, seeking to exclude the votes of Wayne, Washtenaw, and Ingham Counties counties from the state's total vote count because of alleged irregularities.<ref name=":22" /> On November 16, the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the action.<ref name=":23" /><ref name=":24" />
=== ''Michigan Alliance for Retired Americans v. Benson'' ===

On June 2, 2020, the Michigan Alliance for Retired Americans filed suit in Michigan's court of claims against state officials, challenging the requirement for mail-in ballots to be received by election day in order to be counted. Judge Cynthia Stephens granted the request, ordering that county clerks must count ballots postmarked by election day and received up to 14 days after election day.<ref name=":25" /><ref name=":26" /> The state appeals court overruled Stephens, writing that the lower court "abused its discretion by ordering the extension."<ref name=":27" />

title: Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election

Crooked Democrat machines in states like Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin, Georgia, Arizona, and Nevada committed the greatest FRAUD in political history. They manufactured votes in the middle of the night, all of which went to Joe Biden. Dead people “voted” in huge numbers, all for Joe Biden. Ballot signatures were forged and duplicated, all for Joe Biden. Democrat counties unlawfully counted ballots that had not followed proper procedure. Radical Left voting machine companies like Dominion, Smartmatic, and Scytl used their Venezuelan election-rigging software to delete President Trump’s votes and add Biden votes to the fraudulent tally. And worst of all, poll observers were illegally ejected and blocked from having any view of these criminal proceedings. Throughout this, the mainstream corporate media went all out to help steal the election, falsely calling the election for Biden and then relentlessly lying to cover up the massive amount of fraud that had been exposed. Partisan Democrat election officials then rushed to certify the false and fraudulent results of the election for Biden before they could be scrutinized. Just when they thought the election had been successfully stolen, Americans rose up to STOP THE STEAL! The best lawyers in the country, such as American hero Sidney Powell, fought their case in court, revealing overwhelming evidence of massive fraud in corrupt cites on a scale never before seen in American history. They successfully proved that millions of completely illegal votes had been cast for Biden, and millions of Trump votes had been changed or deleted by Dominion and Smartmatic’s election theft software. They also proved that the election was conducted in blatant violation of the United States Constitution, though the illegal blocking of approved poll observers and discrimination against Republican voters. Through this great effort, they were able to successfully block Democrats from abusing power and prematurely certifying fraudulent and falsified results. Great judges then appropriately threw out the millions of illegal and unconstitutional votes that had been cast for Biden. With the help of courageous Republican legislatures in the rigged states, election integrity was restored, and President Trump was awarded the electoral votes he needed for re-election. In the end, this heroic effort by brave lawyers, election officials, judges, and state legislators saved America from the Democrat attempt to rig and steal the election for Joe Biden.

title: Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
added: === ''Arizona Democratic Party v. Hobbs'' ===

On June 10, 2020, the Arizona Democratic Party and the Democratic National Committee filed a lawsuit against Arizona Secretary of State Katie Hobbs in federal court, challenging a state law that requires those who vote by mail to correct missing signatures by election day. On September 10, U.S. District Judge Douglas Rayes ruled for the Arizona Democratic Party. On October 6, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit overruled Rayes, finding that the election day deadline to correct a missing signature imposes a minimal burden on voters.<ref name=":32" />
=== ''Arizona Republican Party v. Fontes'' ===

title: Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
added: === ''California v. Carlos Antonio De Bourbon Montenegro and Marcos Raul Arevalo'' ===

On November 13, two men were charged with allegedly submitting more than 8000 unlawful voter registration applications on behalf of homeless people.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Pair Charged With Voter Fraud Allegedly Submitted Thousands of Fraudulent Applications on Behalf of Homeless People|url=https://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/pair-charged-with-voter-fraud-allegedly-submitted-thousands-of-fraudulent-applications-on-behalf-of-homeless-people/2464168/|access-date=2020-11-19|website=NBC Los Angeles|language=en-US}}</ref> The men, Carlos Antonio De Bourbon Montenegro, 53, and Marcos Raul Arevalo, 34, face a 41-count criminal complaint<ref name=":42">{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Los Anges County Charge Sheet BA491333|url=https://content.govdelivery.com/attachments/CALACOUNTY/2020/11/17/file_attachments/1603710/BA491333.pdf|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=|website=}}</ref> that included “falsifying names, addresses and signatures on nomination papers under penalty of perjury to run for mayor in the city of Hawthorne.” Montenegro is accused of planning to use his home address to collect [[Vote-by-mail in America|vote by mail ballots]] for over 8000 fictitious, non-existent, and deceased voter registrants in order to cast ballots for himself for the office of Mayor of the City of [[Hawthorne, California|Hawthorne]] "and/or other candidates and measures."<ref name=":42" />

title: Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
added: Prior to the election, the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] caused many states to adjust their voting rules and processes. Litigation was initiated by Democrats, seeking measures to ease voting, and Republicans seeking to block such measures.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Chaggaris|first=Steve|title=How the COVID-19 pandemic has changed the US election|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/10/29/how-the-pandemic-has-changed-the-u-s-election|access-date=2020-11-23|website=www.aljazeera.com|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":03">{{Cite web|last=McCoy|first=Alan Gomez and Kevin|title=Federal election lawsuits have already set a recent record. A look at 2020 in the courts.|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2020/10/30/courts-reject-voting-rights-extensions-in-covid-shadowed-elections/5998149002/|access-date=2020-11-23|website=USA TODAY|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":110">{{Cite web|title=COVID-19 and the Most Litigated Presidential Election in Recent U.S. History: How the Lawsuits Break Down|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/article/covid-19-most-litigated-presidential-election-in-recent-us-history/|access-date=2020-11-23|website=FRONTLINE|language=en-US}}</ref> "[M]ore than 230 election-related federal lawsuits were filed from January 1 to October 23, higher than any of the past three presidential election years during the same time period", according to a USA TODAY analysis.<ref name=":03" /> Issues related to mail-in and curbside voting, early voting, voter registration, photo ID and witness signature requirements, and voting rights for convicted felons.<ref name=":110" />

title: Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
added: ==== ''Barnette v. Lawrence'' ====

On November 4, 2020, 4th Congressional District candidate Kathy Barnette sued [[Montgomery County, Pennsylvania|Montgomery County]] officials in federal district court.  Barnette claimed the county's board of elections violated the state's election code by inspecting ballot envelopes for missing information, a process known as pre-canvassing, and by giving voters a chance to correct such deficiencies. Barnett also claimed that the federal equal protection clause was violated because only certain voters were allowed the chance to cure. Barnette asked the county to reject any affected ballots. On November 6, Judge Timothy Savage denied the plaintiffs request.<ref name=":64" /><ref name=":65" /><ref name=":66" />
====''Pirkle v. Wolf''====

On November 10, 2020, four voters sued to block votes from being counted in [[Philadelphia County, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]], [[Montgomery County, Pennsylvania|Montgomery]], [[Delaware County, Pennsylvania|Delaware]] and [[Allegheny County, Pennsylvania|Allegheny]] counties. The plaintiffs claimed the state violated [[Right to equal protection|the right to equal protection]] by allowing counties to have varying practices for mail-in ballots. Porter Wright, the law firm that represented the Trump campaign, asked to withdraw. On November 16, the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the suit. The claims made by plaintiffs in this lawsuit are similar to Brooks v. Mahoney and Bally v. Whitmer; these lawsuits were all filed by conservative lawyer [[James Bopp]]. The plaintiffs also cited Trump v. Boockvar.<ref name=":62" /><ref name=":37" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":63" />
==== ''Ziccarelli v. Allegheny County Board of Elections'' ====

On November 12, 2020, Nicole Ziccarelli, a Republican state Senate candidate, sued the Allegheny County Board of Elections. The plaintiffs claimed that the board improperly counted 2,349 mail-in ballots that were not dated by the voter, and sought to exclude these votes from being counted. On November 18, 2020, the state's Court of Common Pleas denied the plaintiffs request, ordering the votes to be counted. Ziccarelli appealed the decision on November 19; the following day, the state's Commonwealth Court ruled that the election code requires the voter to date their ballot, and the 2,349 ballots in question should not be counted.<ref name=":67" /><ref name=":68" />

title: Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
added: === Post-election lawsuits ===
==== ''Tyler Kistner et al v. Steve Simon, et al'' ====

On November 24, 2020, the same day Minnesota certified the presidential vote, a suit was filed on behalf of numerous candidates from various races within Minnesota, as well as a handful of voters. The suit alleged various election problems and sought a temporary restraining order delaying certification of election results.

In their brief, lawyers for four of the counties involved in the lawsuit said: “The Trump Campaign seeks to needlessly draw out this futile legislation by asserting the right to reinstate meritless claims they excised and abandoned in the District Court in a well-publicized effort to undermine this election and, ultimately, democracy itself,”

title: Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
added: ==== ''King v. Whitmer'' ====

On November 25, 2020, a group of voters filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court Eastern District of Michigan against Gretchen Whitmer, the Governor of Michigan, and other state officials. The plaintiffs complain about "massive election fraud, multiple violations of Georgia laws, including O.C.G.A. §§ 21-2-30(d), 21-2-31, 21-2-33.1 and §21-2-522, and multiple Constitutional violations". The plaintiffs claimed fraudulent activities including "ballot stuffing", electronic fraud using the Dominion Voting machines. Additionally, the plaintiffs also claimed procedural violations such as failures in tallying (failed to verify signatures, check security envelopes, or properly audit election results). As the result, the plaintiffs sought to 1) have the state de-certify the election results; 2) preventing the Governor from transmitting the currently certified election results to the Electoral College; 3) have Governor Kemp transmit certified election results that state that President Donald Trump is the winner of the state election; among other reliefs <ref name="Case 2:20-cv-13134-LVP-RSW">{{cite web |url=https://defendingtherepublic.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Michigan-Complaint.pdf |accessdate=November 25, 2020 |date=November 25, 2020}}</ref>

title: Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
deleted: ==== ''Donald J. Trump for President v. Way'' ====

In August 2020, the Trump campaign sued New Jersey state officials in federal court, seeking to overturn an executive order issued by governor [[Phil Murphy|Phillip Murphy]]. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, Murphy had ordered that mail-in ballots should be sent to all active voters in the state. The Trump campaign argued that the order violates the U.S. Constitution, which gives power to state legislatures to conduct congressional elections and select electors for the U.S. Presidency. Thereafter, the New Jersey state legislature enacted legislation to the same effect as the governor's order. In September, the Trump campaign asked U.S. District Judge Michael Shipp to prohibit vote counting before election day, and the counting of mail-in ballots that are not postmarked and received after election day. On October 6, Judge Shipp denied the request.<ref name=":21" />

title: Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
added: === ''Angelic Johnson, et. al. v. Jocelyn Benson, et. al.'' ===

On November 26, 2020, the Amistad Project<ref>{{Cite news|last=Jaehnig|first=Graham|date=November 24, 2020|title=Amistad Project continues battle over voter integrity|work=[[The Daily Mining Gazette]]|url=https://www.mininggazette.com/news/2020/11/amistad-project-continues-to-battle-voter-integrity/|url-status=live|access-date=November 28, 2020}}</ref> filed ''Angelic Johnson, et. al. v. Jocelyn Benson, et. al.'' as an extraordinary writ<ref>{{cite court|litigants=Angelic Johnson, et. al. v. Jocelyn Benson, et. al.|court=Michigan State Supreme Court|reporter=|vol=|opinion=|pinpoint=|date=2020|url=https://got-freedom.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Motion-for-Immediate-Consideration.pdf|quote=}}</ref> in the Michigan State Supreme Court.

title: Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
Post-election lawsuits related to the 2020 U.S. presidential election
deleted: Throughout 2020, the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] issued at least a dozen orders related to the 2020 primary and general elections.<ref name=":04">{{Cite web|title=Supreme Court referees spate of election battles: What their decisions say about how elections are regulated|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/supreme-court-orders-2020-election-battles/|date=October 30, 2020|first=Melissa|last=Quinn|access-date=2020-11-23|website=www.cbsnews.com|language=en-US|archive-date=November 24, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201124081147/https://www.cbsnews.com/news/supreme-court-orders-2020-election-battles/|url-status=live}}</ref> The court's conservative justices have objected to last-minute changes to elections that are ordered by federal judges, saying the power to administer elections lies solely with state legislatures;<ref name=":04" /><ref name=":111">{{Cite web|last=Kilgore|first=Ed|date=2020-10-29|title=How the Supreme Court Has Already Tinkered With the 2020 Election|url=https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/10/how-the-supreme-court-has-affected-voting-rules-this-year.html|access-date=2020-11-23|website=Intelligencer|language=en-us|archive-date=November 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201118062145/https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2020/10/how-the-supreme-court-has-affected-voting-rules-this-year.html|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2020-10-29 |title=Supreme Court issues flurry of last-minute election orders |url=https://apnews.com/article/supreme-court-election-orders-4820caf0f0e8a7aaa3488f242b633cdf |first=Mark |last=Sherman |access-date=2020-11-23 |website=AP News |archive-date=November 20, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201120001817/https://apnews.com/article/supreme-court-election-orders-4820caf0f0e8a7aaa3488f242b633cdf |url-status=live }}</ref> the court's liberal justices have favored the loosening of election rules. The deciding vote has often fallen to [[Chief Justice of the United States|Chief Justice]] [[John Roberts]], according to [[Jonathan H. Adler|Jonathan Adler]], a professor at the [[Case Western Reserve University School of Law]].<ref name=":04" /> Under Roberts, the court has focused on keeping federal courts out of state elections, and has consistently treated election changes made by state judges or officials more leniently than those made by federal courts.<ref name=":111" />
